author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Revisits the Vice-Presidential Debate
description: The comic Nate Bargatze hosted an episode that opened with another political sketch featuring the guest stars Dana Carvey, Jim Gaffigan, Maya Rudolph and Andy Samberg.
content: Last week, America got the answer to the question: Who would play the presidential and vice-presidential nominees this season on “Saturday Night Live”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: The Robotic Future of Pro Sports
description: We explore a looming change in sports officiating.
content: For most of sports history, there was no recourse when a referee made a bad call. Fans could boo and players could complain, but the game went on. Instant replay changed that a few decades ago, allowing coaches to challenge a call and ask the referees to review it. That made games fairer, but it also made them slower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Shaer
title: A Master Storyteller, at the End of Her Story
description: At 96, Lore Segal is approaching death with the same startling powers of perception she brought to her fiction.
content: In June, in the sort of portentous tableau that would not have been out of place in her own fiction, a leak opened in the ceiling of Lore Segal’s apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. For hours, water splashed across the kitchen countertops and onto the tiled floor, collecting in murky puddles and defying all efforts by Segal and her part-time nursing aide to catch it with buckets or stanch it with spare towels. Only when the building superintendent managed to locate the source of the problem — faulty pipes in the unit above — was the flood finally halted. Segal and the aide and Segal’s grandson Isaiah were left to mop up the mess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris Will Appear in a Whirlwind of Interviews, Most of Them Friendly
description: After mostly avoiding interviews as her campaign began, the vice president will hold several this week, including with Howard Stern, Stephen Colbert and the hosts of “The View.”
content: Vice President Kamala Harris will engage in a media blitz this week, sitting for a series of mostly friendly interviews as her campaign shifts into exhorting her supporters to make sure they cast their votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk Leaps to Trump’s Side in Rally Appearance
description: Mr. Musk, the world’s richest man and the leader of Tesla and X,  delivered a dark warning during an animated appearance at former President Donald J. Trump’s rally.
content: Elon Musk, the billionaire head of Tesla and SpaceX, strode onto the stage to cheers at Donald J. Trump’s rally on Saturday night, lifted his arms above his head and jumped into the air — twice — exposing his navel as his shirt rode up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: How Oct. 7 Changed American Jews
description: In a year of trauma, many Jews have found support in the deep wells of history, community and faith.
content: The turning point came during spring finals, when Abigail Fixel got back to her dorm room at Barnard College and found a small Palestinian flag slapped onto her door frame, where her mezuza should have been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch, Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: At North Carolina Churches After Helene, a Time to Grieve and a Time to Hope
description: Worshipers gathered on Sunday, many for the first time since the storm decimated their communities, “to cry and pray and process.”
content: As people headed toward First Baptist Church Swannanoa on Sunday, it was impossible to forget what had happened to their small mountain community in western North Carolina. Scattered across the landscape were broken pieces of life before the remnants of Hurricane Helene barreled through: chunks of asphalt, shredded trees, fragments of home foundations. Nearby, a search-and-rescue team clambered over debris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Names 21 New Cardinals, Reaching Far Beyond Europe
description: The appointments cement Francis’ imprint on the group that will choose his successor, and reflect his vision of a more truly global Roman Catholic Church.
content: In announcing on Sunday that he would appoint 21 new cardinals, Pope Francis once again elevated clerics from far beyond Catholicism’s traditional centers of power, in line with his vision of a more global, less Eurocentric church. It also further cemented his imprint on the men who will one day choose his successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Maria Abi-Habib, Michael D. Shear and Edward Wong
title: How the Push to Avert a Broader War in Lebanon Fell Apart
description: Diplomats thought both Israel and Hezbollah supported a call for a temporary cease-fire. Then Israel killed Hezbollah’s leader.
content: Everything appeared to be heading in the right direction for a breakthrough in Middle East peacemaking, to avert a spiraling war that would embroil the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: From the Sidelines, Joy and Empowerment on Full Display
description: Sui-Lee Wee, the Southeast Asia bureau chief, reported on women who had fled Myanmar and found refuge — and the delight of soccer — in Thailand.
content: Last year, I was in the Thai city of Mae Sot interviewing a Burmese rock star turned filmmaker when I stumbled across a website that belonged to a nonprofit based in Thailand. The group was helping empower Burmese women migrants — through soccer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: After Helene’s Deluge, Ashville’s Water Crisis Has No End in Sight
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 6, 2024.
content: “I’m not going to provide a timeline, and I’m not going to provide a timeline on when I’ll provide a timeline.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: A Cryptic Letter With a Clear Warning
description: A domestic terrorist group sent a note to The New York Times admitting to detonating a bomb in Queens.
content: Nearly 50 years ago, on Jan. 29, 1975, a bomb exploded inside the State Department’s headquarters in Washington, D.C., damaging the building but causing no injuries. A bomb was discovered that same day at a federal office building in Oakland, Calif., and was safely detonated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: How One Polling Decision Is Leading to Two Distinct Stories of the Election
description: A methodological choice has created divergent paths of polling results. Is this election more like 2020 or 2022?
content: Over the last month, one methodological decision seems to have produced two parallel universes of political polling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Febos
title: The Sexiest Year of My Life Involved Zero Sex
description: When I removed the option of romance, my sensual relationship to all the other aspects of my life deepened.
content: A friend confided to me recently that she was burned out on dating. Cruising the apps in midlife felt humiliating, and she repeatedly confronted the same obstacles in her relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: Pakistan Bans Protest Movement in Renewed Crackdown on Dissent
description: Analysts say the military is expanding its efforts to squash opposition.
content: The Pakistani government on Sunday banned an ethnic Pashtun rights movement that has long criticized the country’s powerful military, the latest sign of a renewed crackdown on public dissent and political opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 6, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 6, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Do Careerism and College Mix?
description: Readers respond to a guest essay by a recent college graduate. Also: New York City’s new outdoor dining program; how immigrants built America.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: A Year After Feinstein’s Death, Her Life’s Belongings Are for Sale
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein collected fine jewelry, paintings and a trove of political mementos. Because of her trust, many of those items are available for public inspection — and purchase.
content: In 1990, Dianne Feinstein retreated to a beach house on the coast of Northern California after she lost a grueling race to become the state’s governor. She was 57, and her political career appeared to have peaked at “mayor of San Francisco.” She told friends that she was thinking about leaving public life for good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Sokolove, Ron Butler, Jack D'Isidoro, Emma Kehlbeck, Krish Seenivasan, John Woo, Aaron Esposito, Maddy Masiello and Devin Murphy
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Blind Side’ Made Him Famous. But He Has a Different Story to Tell.
description: The football player Michael Oher believes his early life was misrepresented by the Oscar-winning movie and the book it was based on.
content: It was an overcast Monday afternoon in late April, and Michael Oher, the former football player whose high school years were dramatized in the movie “The Blind Side,” was driving Michael Sokolove on a tour through a forlorn-looking stretch of Memphis and past some of the landmarks of his childhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mosab Abu Toha
title: Gaza’s Schools Are for Learning, Not for Dying
description: Schools across Gaza have turned into refugee centers, and Israeli attacks on them have killed hundreds.
content: This article has been updated to include news developments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Christopher Flavelle, Michael D. Shear and Tiffany Hsu
title: Another Hurdle in Recovery From Helene: Misinformation Is Getting in the Way
description: In North Carolina and other states, a barrage of conspiracy theories and false claims over efforts to bring relief after Hurricane Helene is alarming and disheartening officials and workers.
content: In the aftermath of Hurricane Helene’s devastation in western North Carolina, the public meeting in Rutherford County last Wednesday was essential business. Officials from several shellshocked communities convened to talk about the extensive damage and ongoing search-and-rescue efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was on an Uptown 1 Coming Home From My Job at a SoHo Restaurant’
description: A briny snack on the subway, love in the air in Park Slope and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisia’s Autocratic Leader Is Poised to Steamroll to Election Victory
description: President Kais Saied, who has jailed opponents and consolidated power, is almost certain to win Sunday’s election in the North African country, the birthplace of the Arab Spring movement.
content: For many Tunisians, there seems to be little point to the presidential election on Sunday. There are barely any candidate posters, no debates and not much suspense. The president, Kais Saied, appears so sure of victory that he has not even issued any policy proposals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Mississippi Roast Two Ways
description: Go with the internet-famous version, or make our from-scratch recipe. Both are objectively fantastic.
content: Good morning. I’ve been making Mississippi Roast for the better part of a decade now, ever since reporting out a story about its origins for The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Philharmonic Returns to Classics, at Its Own Expense
description: Led by Manfred Honeck, the orchestra all too quickly revisited Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony and, with Vikingur Olafsson, Brahms’s Piano Concerto No. 1.
content: A risk of programming standard repertory works over and over is that an orchestra is practically begging to be compared with its own recent performances — not to mention a huge and ever-growing body of recordings. Why should someone buy a ticket to a concert if they just heard the same group do the same piece, or if they can stay home and listen to dozens of masterly versions online?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: 2 Boys Charged in Manhattan Assault on Former Gov. David Paterson
description: The boys, 12 and 13, were charged with gang assault, according to the police. Two adults who were involved in the attack have not been caught, the police said.
content: Two boys have been arrested and charged in a street attack on David A. Paterson, a former governor of New York, and his stepson, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnatan Reiss and Amit Elkayam
title: A Ghostly Life for Those Trickling Back to Villages Attacked on Oct. 7
description: Along Israel’s border with Gaza, reminders of the trauma of the Hamas-led assault are inescapable as the few who have returned try to start anew.
content: Before Oct. 7, Naama Giller let her children roam freely through her Israeli village on the border with Gaza. Her front door was rarely locked. She liked living in a place animated by communal festivities, outdoor life, the din of boys and girls playing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller and Teddy Rosenbluth
title: Some Scientists May Never Win a Nobel, but They Still Deserve Big Prizes
description: The Nobel Foundation offers prizes in only three disciplines, but other awards have been created to honor scientists in different fields.
content: Every October, scientists eagerly await the announcement of the Nobel Prizes in physics, chemistry and medicine. But many researchers outside of those fields may miss out on opportunities for the international acclaim that comes with being named a laureate of the Nobel, the most prestigious award in science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Dylan Freedman, Chevaz Clarke and Aaron Byrd
title: Trump’s Speeches, Increasingly Angry and Rambling, Reignite the Question of Age
description: With the passage of time, the 78-year-old former president’s speeches have grown darker, harsher, longer, angrier, less focused, more profane and increasingly fixated on the past, according to a review of his public appearances over the years.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump vividly recounted how the audience at his climactic debate with Vice President Kamala Harris was on his side. Except that there was no audience. The debate was held in an empty hall. No one “went crazy,” as Mr. Trump put it, because no one was there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Aryn Baker
title: On Social Media, Gazans Share Advice for Those Under Fire in Lebanon
description: A woman known as Chef Hala, who has had to evacuate three times since Israel invaded Gaza, is among those offering practical tips and messages of solidarity.
content: Israel’s invasion of southern Lebanon has forced thousands of people there to grapple with some urgent questions: What should I pack before I evacuate? What should stay behind? And where can I go that might be safe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Tim Walz Makes First Sunday Show Appearance Since Joining Ticket
description: Mr. Walz, who has kept a relatively low profile since becoming Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate, appeared on Fox News Sunday.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota fielded tough questions on abortion, immigration, the economy and his own past misstatements in an interview on “Fox News Sunday,” that was mainly noteworthy because it was his first appearance on a Sunday news program since becoming Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: At a Tennessee Plastics Plant, Sorrow and Uncertainty in Helene’s Wake
description: More than a week after workers fled flooding outside their factory, much remains unclear, including how many died.
content: The few details that are known about Bertha Mendoza’s last moments are heartbreaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alana Semuels
title: Freeports, Free Zones and Other Places With Perks — for the Rich
description: In “The Hidden Globe,” the journalist Atossa Araxia Abrahamian examines the rise of spaces where wealthy countries and companies bend rules and regulations to their advantage.
content: In the early 1960s, an American named Richard Bolin, who was working for the consulting firm Arthur D. Little, pitched an idea to the Mexican government. What if it put factories along its border with the United States and allowed them to produce goods that could be exported duty-free? The goal was to jump-start the economy in the border region while at the same time encouraging free trade. The factories built under this plan, called maquiladoras, exist to this day. The concept behind them — that you could siphon off part of a country and allow it to play by different rules — has spread globally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Return to Scene of Attack Was a Do-Over in More Ways Than One
description: The former president returned to the stage where a gunman tried to kill him in July and tried to recapture some of the momentum he had before President Biden dropped out.
content: Donald J. Trump returned to Butler, Pa., on Saturday for a massive rally at the fairgrounds where he was struck in July by a would-be assassin’s bullet, an event envisioned by his campaign as a show of strength and a memorial for the former volunteer fire chief who was killed during the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Christopher Ciccone, Who Dished About His Sister Madonna, Dies at 63
description: An artist, designer, choreographer and dancer, he was best known for writing a grudge-settling memoir about his formerly close bond with the pop star.
content: Christopher Ciccone, who devoted himself to his older sister Madonna — living with her, warning her of impending arrest and directing her world tours of the early 1990s — but who later, after feeling cast aside, wrote a memoir chronicling experiences that he described as “abuse,” died on Friday. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Blueprint Detail
description: While away the hours with Desirée Penner and Jeff Sinnock.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: One Big Decision Awaits the Supreme Court
description: Will the court resume or refrain from injecting itself into the country’s culture wars?
content: The most important decision the Supreme Court’s justices will make in the new term that begins on Monday transcends the questions presented in any of its many cases. It is whether the court will resume or refrain from injecting itself into the country’s culture wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Antisemitic Incidents Reach New High in the U.S., Report Finds
description: The Anti-Defamation League has found that cases of antisemitism have surged in the wake of the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas against Israel last year.
content: The number of antisemitic episodes in the United States surged to the highest recorded in a one-year period in the wake of the Hamas attack on Israel last year, the Anti-Defamation League said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Tacita Dean Draws Her Way Into the Menil
description: In the artist’s first major U.S. museum survey, she bonds with Cy Twombly through works on paper, films and photographs.
content: During a residency at the Menil Collection in Houston last February, the British artist and filmmaker Tacita Dean spent the night in the Cy Twombly Gallery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: In Talking About ‘Freedom,’ Harris Hopes She Has a Winning Message on Guns
description: The vice president is talking about firearms in a new way for a Democrat — by co-opting the language of Republicans.
content: When President Bill Clinton asked House Democrats to pass an assault weapons ban in 1994, their leaders begged him to back off, fearing the vote would cost them their seats. They were right. Democrats lost the House for the first time in 40 years, blamed the assault weapons ban and let it expire. They have struggled ever since to figure out a winning gun safety message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Jeffers
title: An Artist Rethinks Climate Change in Words and Pictures
description: We need to act as a single unified force to find ways to strike a lasting balance with our natural world.
content: All we are as people is a collection of stories — those we are told, those told about us, those we tell to ourselves and others. They explain our identity and express our values, and they’ve long shaped societies — Sparta as a culture of warriors, America as the land of the free and so on. But when several conflicting stories are being told, they can also limit us, delude us and divide us. Too often they suit only the teller, not the audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Susie Maxwell Berning, Hall of Fame Golfer, Is Dead at 83
description: She often took time away from the tour for her family. But she tallied 11 championships, including three in the U.S. Women’s Open.
content: Susie Maxwell Berning, a trailblazing three-time champion of the United States Women’s Open golf tournament who was known for her tenacity on the fairway and her grace off it, died on Wednesday at her home in Indio, in Southern California. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Evacuation Orders Posted as Florida Braces for Hurricane Milton
description: The powerful, life-threatening hurricane is expected to make landfall on Wednesday even as residents continue to recover from Hurricane Helene.
content: Evacuations and storm preparations began on Sunday night as forecasters projected that Hurricane Milton would slam into Florida’s west coast on Wednesday as a major hurricane packing life-threatening winds and storm surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,206
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 7, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
title: In Ukraine, Small, Fluffy Dogs Offer Wartime Comfort
description: Dog ownership has surged over the past two years as people seek companionship. In Kyiv, Yorkies, poodles and bichons frisés now rule the streets.
content: For two days last month, a vision of canine paradise emerged in the heart of a city regularly pounded by Russian drones and missiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Peter Jay, Headline-Making British Ambassador to the U.S., Dies at 87
description: His appointment sparked criticism and charges of nepotism. He later achieved unwanted attention as a character in the novel “Heartburn.”
content: Peter Jay, a British journalist, broadcaster and diplomat whose tenure as ambassador to the U.S. began and ended in controversy, died on Sept. 22 at his home in Woodstock, England. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel Was Prepared for a Fight With Hezbollah. Ending It Will Be Harder.
description: Lessons learned from a 2006 invasion of Lebanon have guided Israel in its current one. Security experts say a political deal is needed to restore calm.
content: Israel’s last war with Hezbollah, in 2006, was considered a failure within much of the Israeli security establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 5, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 5, 2024.
content: An article on Sept. 29 about the death of the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah referred incompletely to the circumstances that led to military exchanges between Israel and Hezbollah starting last October. Hezbollah began firing on Israeli positions in solidarity with Hamas after the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel that ignited the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Bruised Supreme Court Returns to Bench With Possible Election Cases Looming
description: Aside from major disputes on issues like transgender rights and guns, the docket is fairly routine. That could change fast if the presidential race is contested.
content: The new Supreme Court term, which starts as the justices return to the bench on Monday, already features cases on transgender rights, untraceable “ghost guns” and whether Mexico may sue American firearms manufacturers. The coming months may also bring voting disputes that could decide the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Faludi
title: Kamala Harris Is Turning a Trump Tactic on Its Head
description: Trump wants to position himself as the nation’s protector. But Harris is offering real-world, practical protection on the issues that matter.
content: It’s a truism that female candidates for high office face obstacles that men don’t. Less acknowledged is that women face different obstacles each from the other. Individually and generationally, women confront their own particular impossible dilemmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: JD Vance and the Prophets of Trumpism
description: For this group of Christians, “Trump is good. He’s been baptized by their theology.”
content: On Sept. 28, JD Vance spoke at a Christian political event hosted by the most influential religious leader you’ve probably never heard of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Fear and Uncertainty Overshadow Oct. 7 Memorial Preparations
description: Amid the chaos and the war that followed the Hamas-led assault, Israel has not yet held a national day of mourning for the 1,200 people who were killed.
content: People in Israel were bracing on Sunday to mark the first anniversary of the deadly Hamas-led assault on southern Israel, entering a heavily charged week that promises to be filled with mourning as well as fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Ship in Need of Repairs Has Explosive Cargo, but No Dock
description: The MV Ruby has meandered around Europe’s northwestern coastline under a cloud of suspicion over its thousands of tons of Russian fertilizer.
content: The MV Ruby has languished off the coast of Britain for more than a week, its hull cracked, its propeller damaged. Yet no port will let the ship dock, fearing that the thousands of tons of Russian fertilizer it carries could lead to a disastrous explosion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein, Eliza Shapiro and Jan Ransom
title: The 3 Brothers at the Center of the Bribery Inquiry Rocking City Hall
description: David Banks and Philip Banks III eclipsed their younger brother by rising to help run New York City. Then federal prosecutors seized the phones of all three men.
content: It was an ordinary Friday at City Hall, and Mayor Eric Adams was at the microphone, flanked by two men who each commanded his own vast corner of New York City government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Hedi Slimane Changed Fashion
description: He has just left his fourth job at a big brand. Maybe it’s time he start one of his own. Would you buy that?
content: It took only minutes after LVMH announced that Hedi Slimane would be leaving Celine for the Chanel speculation to start. The brand that Coco built has been without a creative director since June, when Virginie Viard stepped down, and who will get the post has become the hottest guessing game in fashion. Mr. Slimane’s name has been in the mix for months. His status as a free agent gave the rumors more juice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova
title: A Changing Climate Is Scorching the World’s Biggest River
description: As a punishing drought dries up stretches of the Amazon River, Brazil is resorting to dredging to try to keep food, medicine and people flowing along the watery superhighway.
content: The world’s largest river is parched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Melinda French Gates’s New Life: Abortion Politics and Kamala Harris
description: After her divorce from Bill Gates, Ms. French Gates came into her own billions of dollars, with which she could do whatever she chose. She used to insist on appearing nonpartisan, but no more.
content: When Melinda French Gates was running the world’s biggest philanthropy with her husband, Bill Gates, she insisted on staying on the sidelines of politics. She was half of one of America’s most celebrated couples, and she did not want to invite backlash from governments around the globe, to say nothing of getting crosswise with Washington by endorsing someone who could lose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Monday Briefing: Reflecting on a Year of War
description: Plus, Paris Fashion Week’s closing fantasia.
content: It’s been a year since the Hamas-led attacks in Israel on Oct. 7, when officials say 1,200 people were killed and roughly 250 more were kidnapped. Since then, health officials say more than 41,000 Palestinians, many of them civilians and children, have been killed in the subsequent war. The fighting has widened to three fronts, and the path to reaching a cease-fire seems uncertain. To reflect on the past year of war in the Middle East, I spoke to Isabel Kershner, who has been covering Israeli and Palestinian affairs for decades and is based in Jerusalem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Cement Is a Big Polluter. A Plant in Norway Hopes to Clean It Up.
description: Heidelberg Materials is betting it can profit from an expensive process that will reduce the carbon dioxide emitted from one of the world’s most polluting industries.
content: Even in the idyllic Norwegian summer, with anglers casting for mackerel from nearby piers, the century-old cement plant on the edge of the harbor town of Brevik is a forbidding place. The screeching of gulls echoes off the mud- and dust-caked passageways between concrete walls, which rise on the edge of the water like the ramparts of a medieval fortress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: ‘Joker’ Sequel Falls Far Short of Original at the Box Office
description: The bleak musical drama is on track to open to around $40 million, significantly less than what the 2019 version made on its first weekend.
content: The original “Joker,” in 2019, earned 11 Oscar nominations, $1 billion in global box office receipts and created a cultural phenomenon. So it was inevitable that Warner Bros. would make a sequel, with the same director, Todd Phillips, and star, Joaquin Phoenix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Prime Minister’s Chief of Staff, Sue Gray, Resigns
description: Ms. Gray said intense media scrutiny of her role meant she “risked becoming a distraction” to the new Labour government.
content: Sue Gray, the chief of staff to Britain’s prime minister, Keir Starmer, resigned abruptly on Sunday after weeks of speculation about turf wars in Downing Street, a media storm over her pay and questions over responsibility for a series of political errors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 484
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 7, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli and Ken Belson
title: In Salt Lake City, Sports Drive a New Vision for Downtown
description: A proposal to remake the area would please the owner of the city’s N.B.A. and N.H.L. teams. But others, including classical musicians, aren’t so thrilled.
content: In late April, about 60 members of the Utah Symphony were on break during a rehearsal of Massenet’s opera “Thaïs” when the organization’s chief executive, Steve Brosvik, matter-of-factly told them that the county was considering demolishing Abravanel Hall, their world-renowned home, as part of a plan to revamp downtown Salt Lake City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Isabel Kershner and Norimitsu Onishi
title: Israel Steps Up Attacks in Gaza and Lebanon Ahead of Oct. 7 Anniversary
description: Israel appeared to label much of northern Gaza as an evacuation zone and in Lebanon, Israeli airstrikes targeted Hezbollah strongholds, as the region also braced for Israel to hit back at Iran.
content: Israel intensified its fight on two fronts Sunday, stepping up operations against Hamas in Gaza and carrying out more airstrikes on Hezbollah in Lebanon, as the region braced for Israel to hit back at Iran for its barrage of ballistic missiles last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Harris Hits Back at Republican Criticism of Childless Women
description: “All of us understand that this is not the 1950s anymore,” Vice President Kamala Harris told the host of the podcast “Call Her Daddy,” a platform popular with millennial and Gen Z women.
content: For the first time, Vice President Kamala Harris dismissed criticism from some Republicans that she does not have biological children, saying in a podcast interview on Sunday that much of the commentary was “meanspirited” and misunderstood women who either can’t have children or simply did not want to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: A ‘Hallowed Place,’ With a Whiff of Onion Rings and Sun Block
description: Donald Trump returned to the site where he was shot in the ear. For some of his supporters, it was a religious event as much as a campaign rally.
content: “We have fought together,” former President Donald J. Trump told his supporters on Saturday evening. “We have bled together.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Rebecca Suner, Gabriel Blanco, David Seekamp and James Surdam
title: The Fight for Rural America
description: One in five Americans identifies as rural, and since the 1960s, their votes have become increasingly Republican. Astead W. Herndon, a politics reporter and the host of the New York Times podcast “The Run-Up,” examines how Republicans expanded their rural advantage to historic levels and whether Democrats can remain competitive.
content: One in five Americans identifies as rural, and since the 1960s, their votes have become increasingly Republican. Astead W. Herndon, a politics reporter and the host of the New York Times podcast “The Run-Up,” examines how Republicans expanded their rural advantage to historic levels and whether Democrats can remain competitive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Christina Shaman and Laura Salaberry
title: How Trump’s Speeches Raise Questions About Age
description: With President Biden out of the 2024 election, former President Donald J. Trump at 78 is now the oldest major party nominee in U.S. history. Peter Baker, senior White House correspondent at The New York Times, explains the change he found in the former president’s speech after reviewing his rallies, interviews, statements and social media posts.
content: With President Biden out of the 2024 election, former President Donald J. Trump at 78 is now the oldest major party nominee in U.S. history. Peter Baker, senior White House correspondent at The New York Times, explains the change he found in the former president’s speech after reviewing his rallies, interviews, statements and social media posts.
source.name: The New York Times
